Built Clearwater system
Built Clearwater system with story

ClearWater in Ecuador

ClearWater is bringing clean drinking water to indigenous communities in the Ecuadorian Amazon. By building rainwater catchment systems, ClearWater works with communities to provide viable clean water solutions.

Read about where we work ▼

The Nor-Oriente Amazon

The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of our water. In the Ecuadorian Amazon, the water sources are contaminated by decades of reckless oil operations and 30,000 peoples are suffering a health crisis due to the toxins in the water. ClearWater is partnering with five indigenous tribes to directly address this crisis.

Meet the Cofán ▼

Cofán Dureno

Centuries ago, the Cofán people moved down from the foothills of the Andes Mountains to inhabit a large territory in the northern Ecuadorian Amazon. The Cofán have been inspiring protagonists in the 19-year legal battle against the oil companies, yet they continue to suffer from the devastating contamination in their communities, most significantly the lack of clean water.

Read More ▼

Cofán Dureno & ClearWater

  • + 52 Rainwater Catchment Systems
  • + 350 people benefitted
  • + 4 community technicians trained

The ClearWater project broke ground in the community of Cofán Dureno from November, 2011 when 52 rainwater catchment systems were built, providing 350 people with much-needed clean water.

Read More ▼

Meet Gonzálo Criollo

Gonzálo Criollo is the son of renowned Cofán shaman Rufino Criollo, and brother of Cofán musicians Silverio and Claus Criollo. Culture and arts run in his family, but Gonzalo has chosen another path: working with his hands. As a senior technician, Gonzálo brings tremendous support to ClearWater. Read The Full Blog Post

Meet the Secoya ▼

Secoya

The Secoya suffer heavily from oil-related contamination. Rivers have been contaminated, making much of the water unsafe to drink or bathe in; traditional subsistence activities like hunting, fishing, and growing edible crops are at risk.

Read More ▼

Secoya & ClearWater

  • + 17 Rainwater Catchment Systems
  • + 100 people benefitted
  • + 4 community technicians trained

Despite the challenges, the Secoya are highly organized and dedicated to building clean water solutions for their people. Over the months of July and August 2013 ClearWater has installed an additional 56 rainwater systems in Secoya territory.

Read More ▼

Meet Hurlem Piaguaje

Hurlem is one of the three young community technicians of ClearWater. Energetic and always smiling, Hurlem keeps everybody on their toes. His work has shown that he is a quick learner, and highly adaptable. He looks forward to the future where he hopes to become a senior community technician and work in other communities. He hopes that people will have better access to clean water then. Read The Full Blog Post

Meet the Siona ▼

Siona

Like the Secoya, the Siona currently suffer from oil contamination, African palm production, deforestation, and expanding colonist settlement in their territory.

Read More ▼

Siona & ClearWater

  • + 20 Rainwater Catchment Systems
  • + 100 people benefitted
  • + 4 community technicians trained

ClearWater began installation in the Siona community in October 2012 and 20 rain catchment systems were built, benefitting over 100 people. Siona technicians working for ClearWater are dedicated to improving the living conditions for all Siona community members by providing them with clean drinking water.

Read More ▼

Meet Celio Piaguaje

Meet Celio Piaguaje, Siona technician from the community Sototsiayá. At age 40, Celio stands as one of the most experienced workers in the group. Dedicated to agriculture his entire life, Celio truly knows the meaning of hard work. Every day during construction, Celio takes a 45 minute ride on his dugout canoe to be a part of the ClearWater project. Read The Full Blog Post

Meet the Waorani ▼

Waorani

The Waorani were the most recently contacted of all Ecuadorian indigenous peoples. Since first contact in 1956, the Waorani have experienced a rapid and difficult insertion into mainstream Ecuadorian society. Their territories have been greatly reduced, and their remaining lands impacted by logging, oil extraction, and colonist settlement. Oil activity and the construction of oil roads has been severely detrimental to Waorani lands.

Read More ▼

Waorani & ClearWater

  • + 13 Rainwater Catchment Systems
  • + 75 people benefitted
  • + 4 community technicians trained

ClearWater began a pilot project in the Waorani communities in March of 2013 using a new design for metal catchment system frames that will last five times longer than wooden frames. 13 systems were built, benefitting 75 people.

Read More ▼

Visiting Yawepare

It’s a long trip from the Amazonian city of Coca to the Waorani community of Yawepare on the edge of Yasuní National Park in Ecuador, much longer than the actual distance would seem to indicate. After almost an hour at high speeds along a paved portion of the Via Auca, the first road in the region built by Texaco when the company initially began operating in the area, you turn off onto the Via Pindo. Read The Full Blog Post

Meet the Kichwa ▼

Kichwa

The Kichwa of the Amazon are the most numerous of Ecuador’s indigenous Amazonian peoples and have taken cleaning up after the oil companies into their own hands. They have taken the environmental remediation into their own hands, painstakingly cleaning up the mess that the oil companies have left behind.

Read More ▼

Kichwa & ClearWater

  • + 53 Rainwater Catchment Systems
  • + 350 people benefitted
  • + 4 community technicians trained

Installation of 53 catchment systems has already begun in the Kichwa village of Rumipamba, starting in May of 2013, which will benefit approximately 350 people. ClearWater will also be working with other Kichwa communities in the near future, ensuring clean water for all oil-affected indigenous communities.

Read More ▼

Engineers Without Borders

Today, we travelled to the village of Rumipamba home of the Kichwa people. The mission is to observe firsthand the extent of oil contamination in the region and to inspect existing rainwater catchment systems in the area. Going in, we all have some preconceived notions about exactly what this looks like but are not prepared for what lies ahead of us. Read The Full Blog Post
